pybash.util package¶

Submodules¶

pybash.util.conversion_util module¶

pybash.util.conversion_util.autoconvert(s)[source]¶

Utility function for automatically converting strings to booleans, integers or floats.

Parameters:s (str) – String to be converted (e.g. ‘True’, ‘1234’, ‘3.14159’)
Returns: bool, int or float if the value could be converted, string if no conversion
was found.
pybash.util.conversion_util.shell_data(var)[source]¶
Function to convert a python variable to a format compatible with shell commands
  1. If input is None, return None
  2. If input is a file, return the file
  3. For other types, return pybash_helper.to_str(var)
Parameters:var – Variable to be converted
Returns:Converted variable

pybash.util.history_util module¶

pybash.util.history_util.remove_history_item(line_number, initial_history_length=None)[source]¶

Function to remove an item from the readline history since readline.remove_history_item() is not working

Parameters:
  • line_number (int) – History line that will removed
  • initial_history_length (int) – The history length recorded at the start of the Pybash session, used for history management. If the removed line was prior to the initial history length, then this needs to be adjusted.
Returns:

If initial_history_length was provided, the adjusted initial history length is returned

If not, then None is returned
Return type:

int

pybash.util.pipe_util module¶

pybash.util.pipe_util.display_std_pipe(std_pipe)[source]¶

Helper function display a pipe with different variable types :Parameters: std_pipe (list) – Pybash standard pipe list

Returns:
Short display representation of each element of std_pipe. Files, ints or None elements
are kept as-is, for others the variable type is returned. This allows the std_pipe to be printed in debug messages in a short form (especially if some elements of std_pipe are a str)
Return type:list
pybash.util.pipe_util.expand_deque_input(dq)[source]¶

Function to take a deque (which acts as a pipe for python commands) and expand it to an input variable that is compatible with run_shell_cmd() / run_python_cmd(). This attempts to replicate the behaviour of shell commands such as ‘foo > bar 2>&1’

Parameters:dq (collections.deque) – input deque to be converted
Returns:
Python variable compatible with run_shell_cmd() / run_python_cmd()
  • If the deque was empty: None
  • If the deque has len == 1: dq[0]
  • If the deque has len > 1, then check the type of elements in the deque. For str, dict and list, pop each deque element and combine into a single variable. For other types (or inconsistent types) just convert the deque into a list.
pybash.util.pipe_util.expand_std_pipe(std_pipe, stdin, stdout, stderr, use_pipe=False)[source]¶

Function to pick either the std_pipe + stdin/stdout/stderr variables, create pipes and process redirects. If std_pipe is defined, then it takes precedence over stdin/stdout/stderr. This allows functions to accept either a tuple or individual arguments depending on the use case.

Parameters:

  • std_pipe (tuple) – Containing (stdin,stdout,stderr) as one tuple.

  • stdin – File-like object, python variable, subprocess.PIPE, positive integer, or None

  • stdout – File-like object, python variable, subprocess.PIPE, positive integer, or None

  • stderr – File-like object, python variable, subprocess.PIPE, positive integer, or None use_pipe (bool):

    1. If True: an os.pipe() is created and opened, (read,write) file-like objects are returned as a tuple
    2. If False: a collections.deque object is created, which is used instead of pipes for python commands
Special cases for stdin, stdout, stderr:
  1. subprocess.PIPE: a new os.pipe or deque is created (depending on the value of use_pipe).
  2. Positive int: this denotes a redirect. If std_pipe = (stdin,stdout,stderr) and std_pipe[i] is >= 0, then, std_pipe[i] is redirected to the pipe or deque located at std_pipe[std_pipe[i]]. For example: std_pipe = (file_a, file_b, 1), then stderr will be redirected to file_b.
Returns:
Returns (stdin,stdout,stderr) which are all either file-like objects (open file, pipes),
python variables (stdin only), or collections.deque objects.
Return type:tuple
pybash.util.pipe_util.fd_assign(file_d_index, mode, val, std_pipe)[source]¶

Function to redirect file descriptor in the std_pipe element specified by file_d_index

Parameters:
  • file_d_index (int) – Index of std_pipe that will be assigned 0 = stdin, 1 = stdout, 2 = stderr
  • mode (str) – mode to open the file, either ‘r’, ‘w’ or ‘a’
  • val (str) – location that the std_pipe element should be redirected to. This can be a file path (e.g. ‘foo.txt’, or a reference to another file descriptor (e.g. ‘&1’). If the location is a file, the string is replaced with an open file-like object (with the mode specified by mode)
  • std_pipe (tuple) – Contains the current location of (stdin, stdout, stderr)
pybash.util.pipe_util.isfile(v)[source]¶
Function to check if a variable is a file
  • Python 2.x: variable type will be file
  • Python 3.x: variable will be an instance of _io.TextIOWrapper
pybash.util.pipe_util.open_pipe()[source]¶

Function that creates an os.pipe and opens the read / write file handles. This mimics what subprocess.Popen() does under-the-hood, but in order to support redirects, it is useful to have the pipe opened before calling subprocess.Popen().

Ref: https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/master/Lib/subprocess.py

Returns:Contains the (read, write) file-like objects created by opening the pipe.
Return type:tuple
pybash.util.pipe_util.read_close_fd(fd)[source]¶

Utility function used to read an open file-like object and then close it.

pybash.util.pipe_util.to_bool(s)[source]¶

Utility functions for converting string to bool

Parameters:s (str) – either ‘True’, ‘False’ (case insensitive)
Returns:bool

pybash.util.pybash_helper module¶

This file contains helper functions for the Pybash interpreter These functions can be used in a pipeline to facilitate moving between bash and python e.g. “find . | to_list” will get the stdout of “find .” and convert each line to an element in a list

This file will be imported within the interpreters “scope” so that the functions are accessible when using exec(‘…’, self.globals, self.locals)

pybash.util.pybash_helper.from_file(f_name, mode='r')[source]¶

Function to read a file and return the contents as a string

Parameters:
  • f_name (str) – File path to read from
  • mode (str) – Mode to read the file (‘r’, ‘rb’), default = ‘r’
pybash.util.pybash_helper.function_match(s)[source]¶

Function used by Pybash to determine if a command is a pybash_helper function

Parameters:s (str) – Command string which may contain Pybash helper functions
Returns:List of functions found in input string
Return type:list
pybash.util.pybash_helper.python_keyword_match(c)[source]¶

Function used by Pybash to check if a command is a python keyword

Parameters:c (str) – Command which is matched against python keywords
Returns:bool
pybash.util.pybash_helper.show_history()[source]¶

Function to show the Pybash history. This function is invoked by the pybash_cmd.do_history(), allowing the history to be displayed when the user enters the command: ‘history’

pybash.util.pybash_helper.to_dict(s)[source]¶

Function to convert a yaml-formatted string to a dict

Parameters:s (str) – Input string to convert to dict
Returns:dict
pybash.util.pybash_helper.to_file(f_name, d, mode='w')[source]¶

Function to write a python variable to a file

Parameters:
  • f_name (str) – File path to write to
  • d – Python variable to write to file, will be automatically converted to a string for writing
  • mode (str) – Mode to write the file (‘w’, ‘wb’, ‘a’, ‘ab’), default = ‘w’
pybash.util.pybash_helper.to_list(s, ignore_empty_lines=True)[source]¶

Function to convert newline-separated string to a python list.

Parameters:
  • s (str) – Input string to convert to list
  • ignore_empty_lines (bool) – If True, then empty text lines are not included in output list
Returns:

list
pybash.util.pybash_helper.to_str(v, single_line=False)[source]¶

Function to convert input variable to string, using special formatting for dicts and lists. TODO: Add support for json

Parameters:

  • v – input variable to convert to string

  • single_line (bool) – If this flag is True, the variable will be formatted without newlines. 1. Dict: converted to string using yaml.dump()

    1. single_line = True: use default_flow_style=True
    2. single_line = False: use default_flow_style=False
    1. List
      1. single_line = True: Use space character to separate elements (used for bash-like formatting)
      2. single_line = False: Use newline character to separate elements (used for writing to file)
    2. Other variable types: Converted to string using str()
Returns:

String representation of input variable
Return type:

(str)
